source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Euchiton
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Euchiton. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Capitula solitary and terminal, lacking subtending floral leaves longer than capitula; leaves silvery on both surfaces; subalpine and alpine only

Inflorescence a dense terminal cluster of sessile capitula sometimes with smaller clusters in axils of flowering stem), usually immediately subtended by spreading floral leaves longer than capitula; at least the lower leaves usually green (rarely grey-cottony) on upper surface; lowland to subalps
Capitula with only 1 (rarely 2 or 3) bisexual floret; basal rosette leaves either not developed or, usually, withered at flowering; non-stoloniferous annuals
Capitula with more than 1 (up to c. 16) bisexual florets; perennials, often stoloniferous and/or rhizomatous
Inner involucral bracts deeply lacerated at apex; bisexual florets about as many as (sometimes more than) female florets
Inner involucral bracts entire or occasionally the innermost 2- or 3-toothed; bisexual florets many fewer than female florets

Leaves on upper stem much shorter than those of lower stem; clusters of capitula subtended by leafy bracts not or barely exceeding the cluster, their margins usually plane; plants typically not of particularly moist sites

Leaves on upper stem not much shorter than those of lower stem; leafy bracts subtending clusters of capitula at least twice as long as diameter of cluster, their margins often undulate; commonly plants of moist sites
Plants usually strongly erect; stem usually simple; stem leaves noticeably auriculate at base; cypselas puberulous, with minute white hairs
Plants usually diffuse; stems usually branched; stem leaves usually auriculate at base; cypselas glabrous
